abstract.text: An argument of options you pass to a GPU device to get a render pipeline state.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: An

instance configures the state of the pipeline to use during a rendering pass, including rasterization (such as multisampling), visibility, blending, tessellation, and graphics function state. Use standard allocation and initialization techniques to create an
object. Then configure and use the descriptor to create an
object.
To specify the vertex or fragment function in the rendering pipeline descriptor, set the
or
property, respectively, to the desired
object. The system ignores the tessellation stage properties if you don’t set the
property to a post-tessellation vertex function. A vertex function is a post-tessellation vertex function if the
attribute precedes the function’s signature in your Metal Shading Language source. See the “Post-Tessellation Vertex Functions” section of
for more information.
Setting the
property to
disables the rasterization of pixels into the color attachment. This action is typically for outputting vertex function data into a buffer object, or for depth-only rendering.
If the vertex shader has an argument with per-vertex input attributes, set the
property to an
object that describes the organization of that vertex data.
If a color attachment supports multisampling (essentially, the attachment is an
type color texture), you can create multiple samples per fragment, and the following rendering pipeline descriptor properties determine coverage:
is the number of samples for each pixel.
If
is
, the GPU uses the alpha channel fragment output for
to compute a coverage mask that affects the values the GPU writes to all attachments (color, depth, and stencil).
If
is
, the GPU changes alpha channel fragment values for
to
, which is the largest representable value.
If
is
, an implementation-defined
function uses the alpha channel fragment output from
to create an intermediate coverage mask, which sets a number of bits in its output proportionally to the value of the floating-point input. For example, if the input is
, the function sets the output to
. If the input is
, the function sets all output bits (in effect,
). If the input is
, the function sets half of the bits, according to the implementation, which often uses dither patterns.
To determine a final coverage mask, the function performs a logical
on the resulting coverage mask
with the masks from the rasterizer and fragment shader, as the following code shows:

abstract.text: A true value.
Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
An object that represents a public shader function in a Metal library.
An object that configures new render pipeline state objects for mesh shading.
The mutability options for a buffer that a render or compute pipeline uses.
An array of pipeline buffer descriptors.
Options that determine how Metal prepares the pipeline.
The primitive topologies available for rendering.
A color render target that specifies the color configuration and color operations for a render pipeline.
An array of render pipeline color attachment descriptor objects.
An argument of options you pass to a GPU device to get a render pipeline state.
An array of binary archives to search for precompiled versions of the shader.
An array of attachments that store color data.
The pixel format of the attachment that stores depth data.
An array that contains the buffer mutability options for a render pipeline’s fragment function.
The fragment function the pipeline calls to process fragments.
Functions that you can specify as function arguments for the fragment shader when encoding commands that use the pipeline.
The type of primitive topology the pipeline renders.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to read and use the alpha channel fragment output for color attachments to compute a sample coverage mask.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to force alpha channel values for color attachments to the largest representable value.
A Boolean value that determines whether the pipeline rasterizes primitives.
A Boolean value that determines whether the pipeline scales the tessellation factor.
A string that identifies the render pipeline descriptor.
The maximum function call depth from the top-most fragment shader function.
The maximum tessellation factor that the tessellator uses when tessellating patches.
The maximum vertex amplification count you can set when encoding render commands.
The maximum function call depth from the top-most vertex shader function.
The number of samples the pipeline applies for each fragment.
Specifies the default rendering pipeline state values for the descriptor.
The number of samples the pipeline applies for each fragment.
A value that enables or disables shader validation for the pipeline.
The pixel format of the attachment that stores stencil data.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can use the pipeline to create new pipelines by adding binary functions to the fragment shader’s callable functions list.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can use the pipeline to create new pipelines by adding binary functions to the vertex shader’s callable functions list.
A Boolean value that determines whether you can encode commands into an indirect command buffer using the render pipeline.
The size of the control point indices in a control point index buffer.
The format of the tessellation factors in the tessellation factor buffer.
The step function for determining the tessellation factors for a patch from the tessellation factor buffer.
The winding order of triangles from the tessellator.
The partitioning mode that the tessellator uses to derive the number and spacing of segments for subdividing a corresponding edge.
An array that contains the buffer mutability options for a render pipeline’s vertex function.
The organization of vertex data in an attribute’s argument table.
The vertex function the pipeline calls to process vertices.
Functions that you can specify as function arguments for the vertex shader when encoding commands that use the pipeline.
A collection of functions for updating a render pipeline.
An interface that represents a graphics pipeline configuration for a render pass, which the pass applies to the draw commands you encode.
Options for specifying the size of the control point indices in a control point index buffer.
Options for specifying the format of the tessellation factors in a tessellation factor buffer.
Options for specifying the step function that determines the tessellation factors for a patch from the tessellation factor buffer.
Options for choosing the partition mode that the tessellator applies when deriving
the number and spacing of segments for subdividing a corresponding edge.
A two-dimensional texture image that uses more than one sample for each pixel.
A description of a tile-shading render pipeline’s color render target.
An object that configures new render pipeline state objects for tile shading.
An object that describes how to organize and map data to a vertex function.
Define how the Metal translator builds binary archives without precompiled binaries as a starting source.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Compiling Binary Archives from a Custom Configuration Script

abstract.text: Write your Metal pipeline states to a binary archive at app runtime, and build binaries for any supported GPU.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Creating Binary Archives from Device-Built Pipeline State Objects

abstract.text: Run draw commands that render to different outputs using the same vertex data multiple times.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Improving Rendering Performance with Vertex Amplification

abstract.text: Select a destination texture slice in your vertex shader.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Rendering to Multiple Texture Slices in a Draw Command

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
